g.text: Architecture Review: WASM · iOS · Android · Desktop · Backend in Rust

foreignObject.p: A transparent file system lets people work with files across every device without thinking about where data lives. Edits on a laptop appear on a phone; changes in a browser sync to a desktop app. This review asks: can we build this entirely in Rust for browsers, iOS, Android, desktop, and servers? No single crate covers all platforms, but four composed layers can. Layer 1 gives every platform the same file API (§2). Layer 2 keeps the folder tree consistent when multiple devices reorganize files at once (§4). Layer 3 stores content as deduplicated, hash-identified chunks, so editing 1 KB of a 100 MB file only syncs ~64 KB (§3). Layer 4 optionally mounts the virtual FS as a real folder on desktops and servers. The review also covers sync protocols (§5), browser storage (§6), per-file-type strategies (§7), crate recommendations (§8), a phased build plan (§9), and risks (§10).

g.text: The research independently confirmed the same conclusions:
Not kernel-FS everywhere : App-level VFS on clients, optional FUSE on backend/desktop
Content-addressed blobs : File payloads as chunked CAS blobs, referenced by hash
Deterministic op-log : File operations mapped to existing DB sync
Flexible CRDT strategy : Two valid approaches depending on collaboration intensity

foreignObject.p: Each platform has different file, network, and threading capabilities. Servers have full access. Desktops are mostly unrestricted. Browsers are limited to HTTP/WebSocket and OPFS for storage. iOS and Android run Rust natively (not WASM), so they get std::fs and SQLite, but background execution is restricted. This matrix maps what works where.

g.text: Mobile Rust runs natively (aarch64), NOT as WASM. std::fs, diesel, tokio all work.

foreignObject.p: Files are split into variable-size chunks using FastCDC, then each chunk is identified by its BLAKE3 hash instead of by filename. Identical data is stored once (deduplication), and editing a small part of a large file only syncs the changed chunks. A 1 KB edit to a 100 MB file transfers about 64 KB, not the whole file.

g.text: ← same file, 1 KB edit = one changed chunk
> 100 GB: Object storage (S3 blobs, Postgres metadata)

foreignObject.p: Moving folders on two devices at once can create cycles, orphans, or name collisions. Two approaches handle this. SQL-first stores the tree in a regular database with last-writer-wins. Loro LoroTree uses a CRDT (Conflict-free Replicated Data Type) that mathematically prevents invalid states from concurrent moves. The right pick depends on how often users make simultaneous folder changes.

g.text: Folder hierarchy in standard SQL tables.
Risk of orphans under heavy edits
Best for: low concurrency, ship fast
Math-proven tree CRDT. No cycles ever.

foreignObject.p: Sync runs in two phases: metadata first (tree structure, revisions), then content (only missing chunks). Devices see a consistent file hierarchy even before all content downloads. Uploads use a two-phase commit: create a pending revision, upload chunks, then atomically commit. An offline outbox queues operations without connectivity and replays them on reconnect.

g.text: 100 MB file + 1 KB edit = ~64 KB sync
sync_outbox: op_type | payload | device_id | local_seq | sent_at | retry_count

foreignObject.p: Browsers only offer OPFS for persistent database storage, and it requires a dedicated Web Worker for synchronous access. SQLite compiled to WASM runs in that worker and talks to the UI via postMessage (an in-browser, same-tab channel, not a network protocol). Server sync uses HTTP/WebSocket as described in §5.

g.text: SQLite MUST run in Worker. OPFS sync handles are Worker-only. Call navigator.storage.persist() at startup.

foreignObject.p: Different files need different treatment. Small configs store as single chunks. Large videos and scientific data use bigger chunks. Compressed binary formats (BAM, CRAM, mzML) get no sub-file dedup benefit from CDC but still benefit from chunked transfer. This section maps each file type to its chunk parameters, sync priority, and processing location.

Not every Rust crate compiles to every platform or is production-ready. This matrix groups relevant crates into four tiers: must-have (both tracks agreed), platform-specific (certain targets only), evaluate (depends on tree strategy from §4), and avoid (known limitations). Entries include versions and WASM compatibility.

Five incremental phases, each with a testable milestone. Phase 1: core library (chunking, hashing). Phase 2: native and server backends. Phase 3: WASM adapter with OPFS. Phase 4: tree strategy decision based on real benchmarks. Phase 5: iOS, Android, and optional FUSE mount.

Eleven risks rated by severity and likelihood. The biggest: iOS/Android platform bridges require Swift and Kotlin wrappers for File Provider and DocumentsProvider APIs. Other concerns: browser storage eviction, CRDT memory growth, and making conflict resolution understandable to users.

svg.text: Crate versions verified via docs.rs, crates.io, and GitHub
